<<<api>>>: Iterator.next
<<<code>>>: for(Iterator<DataSnapshot> it = dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator(); it.hasNext(); ){
i = i + 1;
names.add(it.next().getValue(String.class));
}
<<<explanation>>>: You're creating a new dataSnapshot.getChildren().iterator() in every iteration of your loop. Try to just use the value of the foreach inside the loop.

To append the elements of one Set to the elements of another Set using Java 7, you can use the following code:

Set<String> set1 = new TreeSet<String>();
set1 = set1.addAll(set2);
set3 = new TreeSet<String>();
set3 = set3.addAll(set1);

This will add all the elements of set2 to set1 and then add all the elements of set1 to set3.

The output of the code will be:

set3 = [AB, CD, EF]
